--- title: "Class 10: Halloween mini project" author: "Ashley Mazon (PID: A17478903)" format: html toc: TRUE --- ## Background As it is nearly Hallowneen and the halfway point in the quarter let's do a mini project to help us figure out the best candy! Out come from the 538 website and is available as a CSV file: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy <- read.csv("candy-data.txt", row.names = 1) head(candy) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat crispedricewafer 100 Grand 1 0 1 0 0 1 3 Musketeers 1 0 0 0 1 0 One dime 0 0 0 0 0 0 One quarter 0 0 0 0 0 0 Air Heads 0 1 0 0 0 0 Almond Joy 1 0 0 1 0 0 hard bar pluribus sugarpercent pricepercent winpercent 100 Grand 0 1 0 0.732 0.860 66.97173 3 Musketeers 0 1 0 0.604 0.511 67.60294 One dime 0 0 0 0.011 0.116 32.26109 One quarter 0 0 0 0.011 0.511 46.11650 Air Heads 0 0 0 0.906 0.511 52.34146 Almond Joy 0 1 0 0.465 0.767 50.34755 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(flextable) flextable::flextable(head(candy,10)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: > Q1. How many different candy types are in this dataset? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} nrow(candy) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 85 ``` ::: ::: > Q2. How many fruity candy types are in the dataset? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sum(candy$fruity) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 38 ``` ::: ::: > Q3. What is your favorite candy in the dataset and what is it’s winpercent value? My favorite winpercent ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy["Reese's Peanut Butter cup", ]$winpercent ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 84.18029 ``` ::: ::: > Q4. What is the winpercent value for “Kit Kat”? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy["Kit Kat", ]$winpercent ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 76.7686 ``` ::: ::: >Q5. What is the winpercent value for “Tootsie Roll Snack Bars”? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy["Tootsie Roll Snack Bars", ]$winpercent ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 49.6535 ``` ::: ::: ## Quick overview of the dataset ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library("skimr") skimr::skim(candy) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Table: Data summary | | | |:------------------------|:-----| |Name |candy | |Number of rows |85 | |Number of columns |12 | |_______________________ | | |Column type frequency: | | |numeric |12 | |________________________ | | |Group variables |None | **Variable type: numeric** |skim_variable | n_missing| complete_rate| mean| sd| p0| p25| p50| p75| p100|hist | |:----------------|---------:|-------------:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|:-----| |chocolate | 0| 1| 0.44| 0.50| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▆ | |fruity | 0| 1| 0.45| 0.50| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▆ | |caramel | 0| 1| 0.16| 0.37| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |peanutyalmondy | 0| 1| 0.16| 0.37| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |nougat | 0| 1| 0.08| 0.28| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▁ | |crispedricewafer | 0| 1| 0.08| 0.28| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▁ | |hard | 0| 1| 0.18| 0.38| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |bar | 0| 1| 0.25| 0.43| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▂ | |pluribus | 0| 1| 0.52| 0.50| 0.00| 0.00| 1.00| 1.00| 1.00|▇▁▁▁▇ | |sugarpercent | 0| 1| 0.48| 0.28| 0.01| 0.22| 0.47| 0.73| 0.99|▇▇▇▇▆ | |pricepercent | 0| 1| 0.47| 0.29| 0.01| 0.26| 0.47| 0.65| 0.98|▇▇▇▇▆ | |winpercent | 0| 1| 50.32| 14.71| 22.45| 39.14| 47.83| 59.86| 84.18|▃▇▆▅▂ | ::: ::: > Q6. Is there any variable/column that looks to be on a different scale to the majority of the other columns in the dataset? The winpercent is on a 0-100 scale and the rest are 0-1. > Q7. What do you think a zero and one represent for the candy$chocolate column? zero means it doesn't contain any chocolate and one means that chocolate is present > Q8. Plot a histogram of winpercent values ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) ggplot (candy) + aes(x=winpercent) + geom_histogram(bins= 20) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: > Q9. Is the distribution of winpercent values symmetrical? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot (candy) + aes(x=winpercent) + geom_density() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The distribution is not symmetrical as it is slightly skewed to the right. > Q10. Is the center of the distribution above or below 50%? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(candy$winpercent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. 22.45 39.14 47.83 50.32 59.86 84.18 ``` ::: ::: The center of the distribution is below 50%, it is observed to peak around 40% due to a median of 47.83%. > Q11. On average is chocolate candy higher or lower ranked than fruit candy? for chocolate: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # 1. Find all chocolate candy in the dataset choc.inds <- candy$chocolate == 1 # 2. Find their winpercent values choc.win <- candy[choc.inds, ]$winpercent # 3. Calculate the mean of these values choc.mean <- mean(choc.win) choc.mean ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 60.92153 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # 4-6. Do the same for fruity candy # 7. Compare mean winpercents of chocolate vs. fruity # 8. Pick the highest as the winner ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mean(candy[candy$chocolate==1,]$winpercent) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 60.92153 ``` ::: ::: for fruity: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fruit.inds <- candy$fruity == 1 fruit.win <- candy[fruit.inds, ]$winpercent fruit.mean <- mean(fruit.win) fruit.mean ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 44.11974 ``` ::: ::: > Q12. Is this difference statistically significant? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} t.test(choc.win, fruit.win) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Welch Two Sample t-test data: choc.win and fruit.win t = 6.2582, df = 68.882, p-value = 2.871e-08 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 11.44563 22.15795 sample estimates: mean of x mean of y 60.92153 44.11974 ``` ::: ::: The difference is statisically significant due to a low p value of 2.817e-08. ## Overall Candy Rankings > Q13. What are the five least liked candy types in this set? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.5 ✔ forcats 1.0.1 ✔ stringr 1.5.2 ✔ lubridate 1.9.4 ✔ tibble 3.3.0 ✔ purrr 1.1.0 ✔ tidyr 1.3.1 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ purrr::compose() masks flextable::compose() ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} candy %>% arrange(winpercent) %>% head(5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat Nik L Nip 0 1 0 0 0 Boston Baked Beans 0 0 0 1 0 Chiclets 0 1 0 0 0 Super Bubble 0 1 0 0 0 Jawbusters 0 1 0 0 0 crispedricewafer hard bar pluribus sugarpercent pricepercent Nik L Nip 0 0 0 1 0.197 0.976 Boston Baked Beans 0 0 0 1 0.313 0.511 Chiclets 0 0 0 1 0.046 0.325 Super Bubble 0 0 0 0 0.162 0.116 Jawbusters 0 1 0 1 0.093 0.511 winpercent Nik L Nip 22.44534 Boston Baked Beans 23.41782 Chiclets 24.52499 Super Bubble 27.30386 Jawbusters 28.12744 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(5,1,10,4) #sort(x) order(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 4 1 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #candy$winpercent ``` ::: > Q14. What are the top 5 all time favorite candy types out of this set? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} candy %>% arrange(desc(winpercent)) %>% head(5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` chocolate fruity caramel peanutyalmondy nougat Reese's Peanut Butter cup 1 0 0 1 0 Reese's Miniatures 1 0 0 1 0 Twix 1 0 1 0 0 Kit Kat 1 0 0 0 0 Snickers 1 0 1 1 1 crispedricewafer hard bar pluribus sugarpercent Reese's Peanut Butter cup 0 0 0 0 0.720 Reese's Miniatures 0 0 0 0 0.034 Twix 1 0 1 0 0.546 Kit Kat 1 0 1 0 0.313 Snickers 0 0 1 0 0.546 pricepercent winpercent Reese's Peanut Butter cup 0.651 84.18029 Reese's Miniatures 0.279 81.86626 Twix 0.906 81.64291 Kit Kat 0.511 76.76860 Snickers 0.651 76.67378 ``` ::: ::: > Q15. Make a first barplot of candy ranking based on winpercent values. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot (candy) + aes( winpercent, rownames(candy))+ geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: > Q16. This is quite ugly, use the reorder() function to get the bars sorted by winpercent? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot (candy) + aes( x=winpercent, y=reorder(rownames(candy),winpercent)) + geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Add some color based on the "type of candy" ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} my_cols <- rep("black", nrow(candy)) my_cols[as.logical(candy$chocolate)] = "chocolate" my_cols[as.logical(candy$bar)] = "brown" my_cols[as.logical(candy$fruity)] = "pink" ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(candy) + aes(winpercent, reorder(rownames(candy),winpercent)) + geom_col(fill=my_cols) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: > Q17. What is the worst ranked chocolate candy? The worst ranked chocolate candy is Sixlet. > Q18. What is the best ranked fruity candy? The best ranked fruity candy is Starburst ## Winpercent and Pricepercent A plot with both variables/columns winpercent and pricepercent ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggrepel) my_cols[as.logical(candy$fruity)] <-"red" ggplot(candy) + aes(x= winpercent, y= pricepercent, label = rownames(candy)) + geom_point(col=my_cols)+ geom_text_repel(max.overlaps = 7) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: ggrepel: 44 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider increasing max.overlaps ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: > Q19. Which candy type is the highest ranked in terms of winpercent for the least money - i.e. offers the most bang for your buck? Reeses Miniatures >Q20. What are the top 5 most expensive candy types in the dataset and of these which is the least popular? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ord <- order(candy$pricepercent, decreasing = TRUE) head( candy[ord,c(11,12)], n=5 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` pricepercent winpercent Nik L Nip 0.976 22.44534 Nestle Smarties 0.976 37.88719 Ring pop 0.965 35.29076 Hershey's Krackel 0.918 62.28448 Hershey's Milk Chocolate 0.918 56.49050 ``` ::: ::: Nik L Lip, Ring pop, Nestles Smarties, Hershey's Krackle, Hershey's Milk Chocolate. The least popular is Nik L Lip. ## Exploring the correlation structures Now that we've explored the dataset a little, we'll see how the variables interact with each other... the corrplot package to plot a correlation matrix. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(corrplot) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` corrplot 0.95 loaded ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cij <- cor(candy) corrplot(cij) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Principal Component Analysis The function to use is called `prcomp()` with an optional `scale=T/F` argument. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pca <- prcomp(candy, scale =TRUE) summary (pca) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Importance of components: PC1 PC2 PC3 PC4 PC5 PC6 PC7 Standard deviation 2.0788 1.1378 1.1092 1.07533 0.9518 0.81923 0.81530 Proportion of Variance 0.3601 0.1079 0.1025 0.09636 0.0755 0.05593 0.05539 Cumulative Proportion 0.3601 0.4680 0.5705 0.66688 0.7424 0.79830 0.85369 PC8 PC9 PC10 PC11 PC12 Standard deviation 0.74530 0.67824 0.62349 0.43974 0.39760 Proportion of Variance 0.04629 0.03833 0.03239 0.01611 0.01317 Cumulative Proportion 0.89998 0.93832 0.97071 0.98683 1.00000 ``` ::: ::: Our main PCA result figure ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot (pca$x) + aes(PC1,PC2, label = rownames(pca$x)) + geom_point(col=my_cols) + geom_text_repel(col=my_cols) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: ggrepel: 23 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider increasing max.overlaps ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: We should also examine the variable "loadings" or contributions of the original variables to the new PCs ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(pca$rotation) + aes(PC1, rownames(pca$rotation))+ geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](class-10-halloween-mini-project_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Interactive plots that can be zoomed on and "brushed" over can be made with the **plotly** package. It's output is interactive and will not render to PDF :(
